intro: Jacquemontia canescens, commonly known as the hairy jacquemontia, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a herbaceous perennial that belongs to the family Convolvulaceae, which includes morning glory plants. The plant is characterized by its hairy stems and heart-shaped leaves, and it produces showy, trumpet-shaped flowers that are typically pale yellow to orange in color. Jacquemontia canescens thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, often found in rocky or arid environments. Its botanical features make it an interesting subject for both ecological studies and horticultural cultivation.
